And an interesting twist, too, was that the attorney general of the state of New York,
Robert Abrams, filed an amicus brief supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals
that the law was not constitutional. So you had, in effect, the state's attorney general
and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue.
NGRA filed...
NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court arguing that the petition was impromptu
granted and that they would just throw the whole thing out without deciding it. And what
we're hoping is that they are not going to read the underlying issues because, for one
thing, they're not properly before the court. There wasn't an issue in the lower court decision.
And secondly, they were not adequately briefed because, as I said, it was not an issue.
Oral arguments have already been presented in that case. We're expecting a decision later
this spring.
And depending on what happens in that case, it could have a significant impact in New York's litigation for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security clearances are necessary for people,
many people who work for the government or work for private industry that do contracts with the government, generally in the areas of energy and...
defense. And what security clearance means is that the government says that you are okay to look at classified information.
To feel that you're not going to default this information. There's different levels of security clearances. Gay people over the years have had a great deal of problems
giving security clearances. And what we found is that the government's policy on this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have a...
an inter-agency plan or set of guidelines or criteria.
agency decides on its own, and there's an awful lot of discretion
that can be exercised. What we found is a recent trend where in many
agencies, a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I call them
the police agencies, the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency
are hanging in there tough, and they will not
grant security clearance to anybody that they know is gay.
There's been some recent litigation against the CIA.
There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia
District Court. It's before Judge Barrington Parker,
and he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case
for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles
in the U.S. District Court down there involving John Green,
who was an engineer with a company known as TRW.
He's worked with
TRW, I believe, for 13 years, and he's never had any problems.
The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information,
divulged any information, but basically what they said was that he was gay,
that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay, and therefore
made divulged information. So that argument breaks down when a person says,
I'm not subject to blackmail. I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows.
My friends know. There's no big deal to me. I don't know why it's a big deal to you,
but to the CIA, it's a big deal to me.
The CIA is still a big deal, and they just cannot understand why there might not be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court.
The government just yesterday filed a motion to dismiss.
They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case based on solemn immunity.
They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case.
And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government
by getting involved in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not.
So there will be a responsible plea filed on that on March 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefness.
On the First Amendment cases that we're involved in,
we find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco,
we have the Bay Area Reporter, are being censored at a number of prisons around the country.
Prisons that want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit probably at, if we're lucky, the Congressional Correctional Act Institute in Kentucky and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison.
And possibly one down in Texas, as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes.
And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the university.
The two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said, Gay Pride Week.
And the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared.
Because we found out from sort of some of our sources post-administration that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year.
Because they had probably been in some pretty serious trouble.
And so the next year, we made an application to put up the banner and ended up without any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971.
Last year, they allowed that gay students be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot.
But it's not going to be worth anything.
It's not going to be enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school, another school in Michigan called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in the suburb of Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework.
He said this person's gay and he doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools.
And he can't handle his degree.
So they signed him at the University of Arkansas in Batesville.
The school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there.
But they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big gay rights case before I came to the White House.
Before I came to the West Coast involving the lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
Because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate into the law school gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People are raised in a way that they're maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community.
It's sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about.
It's writing these new laws about diversity in the country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality that have not been treated?
Because that seems to be something in California.
And it is sort of an issue.
And it's very complicated.
Yeah.
There's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us.
Which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
A day doesn't go by.
They don't get at least one call.
So they can think about some kind of discrimination or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
The thing that you do talk about when it comes to housing.
I'm reminded of something you pointed out.
That this city, Denver, has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together.
And this is often against gay couples.
What's the status of those?
And has anything been done about it?
We haven't had any complaints in a long time.
About that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright.
Saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay.
But was intended to keep noise down.
And to protect sort of family type environments.
But it certainly can have an impact on gay people.
Some years like that, it's very subtle with legislation.
Some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.
